questions.text: Which of the following conditions is correctly matched with its layer of origin?
questions.solution:
The area marked ‘2’ depicts the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids. In ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome, excess cortisol is produced from this layer. 

Parts of the adrenal glands:

  • The adrenal cortex is arranged in a zonal configuration in three zones - 
    • Outer zona glomerulosa- secretes mineralocorticoids (aldosterone)
    • Middle zona fasciculata- secretes glucocorticoids (cortisol, corticosterone)
    • Inner zona reticularis- secretes androgens (dehydroepiandrosterone)
  • The adrenal medulla- stores and secretes catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine)

On histological examination, the different layers are identified as:

  • Outer zona glomerulosa - small, compact cells
  • Central zona fasciculata - larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial columns
  • Inner zona reticularis - pigmented, compact cells
  • Adrenal medulla - thin layer of large chromaffin cells

Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine producing tumour derived from chromaffin cells and arises from the adrenal medulla.

Option C: In Conn’s syndrome, excess aldosterone is secreted from zona glomerulosa.

Option D: Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla.

The cells of the glomerulosa are arranged in round-to-oval clusters that resemble renal glomeruli, and hence, this layer is called "glomerulosa".

questions.text: An adrenal incidentaloma was detected in a patient who underwent evaluation for renal calculi. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?

choices.text: The majority of these adrenal masses are functional tumours
The likelihood of the adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma is independent of the size of the mass
The only indication for biopsy of this adrenal mass is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis

questions.solution:
The only indication for an adrenal gland biopsy is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis.

An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected on imaging performed for indications other than evaluation for adrenal disease. The majority of these lesions are non-functional tumours i.e. benign. The likelihood of an adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma increases with the size of the mass (25% chance if size >4 cm).

Incidentalomas are evaluated to classify them as functional and non-functional. Non-functional incidentalomas <4cm are managed conservatively with MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If >4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

Note: An adrenal mass should never be biopsied until a pheochromocytoma has been biochemically excluded.

questions.text: A patient being evaluated for primary aldosteronism underwent selective adrenal venous sampling. A comparison of the samples obtained from both the adrenal veins showed a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio. What is the preferred line of treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Medical treatment with spironolactone and supplemental antihypertensives

questions.solution:
During selective adrenal vein sampling, a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio on one side indicates unilateral hyperaldosteronism. In this case, unilateral laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice.

Primary hyperaldosteronism (PHA) is characterized by hypersecretion of aldosterone with suppressed plasma renin levels (due to the negative feedback). The most frequent cause of PHA is unilateral adenoma.

CT or MRI is used to detect the tumour. In a patient with bilateral micronodular hyperplasia, there could be a unilateral non-functioning tumour. Selective adrenal vein sampling can be done to differentiate between unilateral and bilateral disease.

Conservative management with 3-6 months of MRI surveillance is done in non-functional adrenal tumours of < 4cm.

Medical management is done in patients with bilateral disease, the commonly implemented therapeutic approach is treatment with spironolactone and antihypertensive medication.

Surgical management is done in unilateral and asymmetrical bilateral disease by unilateral laparoscopic adrenalectomy. A subtotal resection can be considered in the case of a typical single Conn’s adenoma. However, it is not superior to unilateral adrenalectomy.

questions.text: You are asked to perform sequential adrenal vein sampling in a patient with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Which of the following is the correct sequence of veins that you will go through to test the left adrenal gland?

choices.text: Femoral vein→IVC→right renal vein→right adrenal vein
Femoral vein→IVC→left renal vein→left adrenal vein
Femoral vein→IVC→left gonadal vein→left adrenal vein

questions.solution:
The correct sequence encountered during sequential venous sampling is femoral vein→IVC→left renal vein→left adrenal vein. 

On the right side, the order is femoral vein→IVC→right adrenal vein.

questions.text: A patient was found to have an elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol level and elevated ACTH. On administration of high-dose dexamethasone, ACTH levels were suppressed. MRI of the pituitary gland shows no enlargement. What is the next best step?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest and abdomen
CT scan/ MRI to assess the adrenals
Venous sampling from the inferior petrosal sinus

questions.solution:
The given scenario of elevated ACTH levels that respond to high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is indicative of a pituitary source of hypercortisolism. Since the MRI pituitary is inconclusive, the next best step is to perform a venous sampling from the inferior petrosal sinus.

The stepwise approach to hypercortisolism is as follows: 

  • Confirmation: This includes 2 steps:
    • Tests to detect hypercortisolism (≥2 abnormal test results):
      • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol 
      • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion
      • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST)
      • Low dose DST
    • Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome:
      • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test
  • Identifying the source 
  • Localizing the lesion

questions.text: A patient with Cushing’s syndrome presents with deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following mechanisms do not contribute to this?
questions.solution:
Increased factor V does not contribute to the risk of thromboembolic complications like DVT in a patient with Cushing's Syndrome. 

There is increased factor VIII, vWF, and decreased fibrinolysis in Cushing’s syndrome patients which causes an increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications.

Patients with Cushing's Syndrome are at a greater risk of acquiring hospital-acquired infection, thromboembolic and myocardial complications. Therefore, prophylactic anticoagulants and antibiotics constitute an essential component of pre-operative management.

questions.text: Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in all of the following conditions except

choices.text: Unlocalised primary tumour of the adrenals

questions.solution:
Unilateral adrenalectomy is done in adrenal incidentaloma with a size >4cm. 

Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in: 

  • Bilateral ACTH-independent disease
  • Ectopic ACTH-dependent Cushing’s Syndrome
  • Irresectable or unlocalized primary tumor 

Adrenalectomy is done as a surgical measure in severe hypercortisolism or Cushing's disease. The adrenalectomy can be unilateral or bilateral depending on whether the tumor autonomously secrete hormones that could have a detrimental effect on health or If the adrenal mass benign or malignant.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient has undergone unilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s syndrome and you have been asked to start him on cortisol supplementation, post-surgery. What is the rationale behind it?

choices.text: Remaining  adrenal gland has insufficient reserve
Contralateral adrenal gland is suppressed by prolonged cortisol over-secretion

questions.solution:
The rationale behind cortisol supplementation after the surgical removal of the adenoma is that there is suppression of the contralateral adrenal gland by the pre-operative elevated cortisol levels. This causes primary adrenal insufficiency.

Patients undergoing unilateral adrenalectomy typically require exogenous steroids for up to a year, which is usually the duration the remaining adrenal gland takes to recover adequate function. In bilateral adrenalectomy, steroids are required indefinitely, and patients may also require mineralocorticoid replacement therapy. 

Option A: The remaining adrenal gland usually has sufficient reserve to maintain homeostasis.

Option C: A deficiency of ACTH causes secondary adrenal insufficiency. However, the adrenal insufficiency post adrenalectomy is primary i.e due to the hyposecretion of cortisol from the gland itself. 

Option D: Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome is a bilateral adrenal infarction associated with meningococcal sepsis and is rapidly fatal unless immediately treated.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of new-onset hyperpigmentation of the skin. He had undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s disease 2 years ago. Which of the following statements is not true regarding his current condition?

choices.text: It is characterized by elevated ACTH
Glucocorticoid replacement has to be continued
Screening is done using brain MRI

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of new-onset hyperpigmentation post-adrenalectomy is suggestive of Nelson’s syndrome. The first-line and definitive management is surgical resection of the pituitary adenoma.

Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.

The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or formation of a new one.

Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Excessive ACTH secretion
  • Corticotroph adenoma

Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.

The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

questions.text: Pheochromocytoma is a ten percent tumor. Which of the following statements is false about pheochromocytoma?

choices.text: 10% of pheochromocytomas are seen in children

questions.solution:
10% of pheochromocytomas are bilateral.

Related Pearl: Rule of Tens in Pheochromocytoma

Rule of 10s in Pheochromocytoma includes :

  • 10% are bilateral
  • 10% are extra- adrenal
  • 10% are malignant
  • 25-33 % are inherited.

Note: Symptomatic patients do not follow the Rule of 10's

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient admitted for evaluation of treatment-resistant hypertension and paroxysmal palpitations was found to have elevated metanephrines on urine screen. What is the next best step in the clinical management of this patient?

choices.text: Imaging study with an MRI scan
Medical pre-treatment with phenoxybenzamine followed by laparoscopic resection
Imaging study with a contrast CT scan

questions.solution:
​​In this scenario, the elevated urinary metanephrines point towards the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Hence, the next best step is an MRI to localise the site of the tumour. 

MRI is preferred for the localization of pathologies because contrast media used for CT scans can provoke paroxysms. Classically, pheochromocytomas show a ‘Swiss cheese’ configuration.

123 Iodine-MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is essential for the detection of multiple extra-adrenal tumours and metastases, but PET scan using FDG or DOPA is more sensitive in detecting metastatic foci.

The image given below shows MRI (marked B and C) and high uptake on 123I-mIBG scintigraphy (marked D and E)

Laparoscopic resection is now a routine in the treatment of pheochromocytoma.

An α-adrenoreceptor blocker, phenoxybenzamine, is used pre-operatively to block excess catecholamine and its consequences during surgery. β-blocker is added if there is tachycardia or arrythmia.

questions.text: Germline mutations of which of the following genes is not associated with hereditary pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Germline mutation in NF2 gene is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2, and not hereditary pheochromocytoma. Hereditary pheochromocytomas are associated with NF1 germline mutations. 

Pheochromocytomas can occur in isolation or can be associated with hereditary tumor syndromes with the specific germline mutations such as:  

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 - mutation in NF1 gene
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome - mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) - activating germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome - mutations in VHL gene

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypotension with no presence of bleeding and bilateral adrenalectomy is suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.

Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal or addisonian's crisis) is a medical emergency caused due to a precipitating illness unmasking insufficiency or trauma or severe sepsis causing adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome) or surgical removal of the glands. It presents with non-specific symptoms such as shock with fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hypocalcemia and electrolyte imbalances. It may be often misdiagnosed as an acute abdominal emergency.

Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal pathology), secondary (due to pituitary pathology- lack of ACTH) or tertiary (due to hypothalamus pathology- lack of CRH). 

Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency worldwide.

Tuberculosis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in India.

Adrenal crisis requires immediate intervention owing to its high mortality rate. Immediate rehydration is initiated with a saline infusion at 1 litre/hr with continuous cardiac monitoring. Glucocorticoid replacement is initiated with an initial bolus injection of hydrocortisone 100 mg followed by 200 mg over 24 hours, preferably by continuous infusion or alternatively by IV or IM injections. Mineralocorticoid replacement is initiated once the daily dose of hydrocortisone has been reduced to <50 mg, since hydrocortisone at higher doses provides sufficient stimulation of mineralocorticoids.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: Neuroblastoma can originate in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma does not originate in the adrenal cortex.

Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. There­fore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including:

  • Adrenal medulla - most common site
  • Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia
  • Sympathetic para­ ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl

Note: Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extradural) tumour in children and the most common overall tumour in infants.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl child with failure to thrive was found to have a palpable, firm, irregular abdominal mass that crossed the midline. CT revealed a calcified mass near the left kidney which on biopsy showed Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: 70% patients present with metastasis at diagnosis
Urine homovanillic acid is used for screening
Amplification of N-myc gene is a good prognostic factor
Abdominal mass is a common presentation of the condition

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of neuroblastoma and amplification of N-myc gene is an indicator of poor prognosis.

Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla. Homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelic acid(VMA) are elevated in the urine of approximately 95% of patients and are used to diagnose and monitor this tumor. 

Clinical features:

  • Abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)
  • Periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbital metastases)
  • Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • Hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines

Metastatic disease is present in more than 70% of patients at presentation.

Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histologically, classic neuroblastomas are composed of small, immature ganglion cells with dark nuclei. Typically, Homer-Wright pseudorosettes can be found which are tumour cells concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil.

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumour and chemotherapy.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of adrenal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation in patients with adrenal carcinoma is Cushing’s syndrome due to excess cortisol.

Patients with non-functioning tumours frequently complain of abdominal discomfort or back pain (large tumours).

Mc Farlane classification is used for staging adrenal carcinoma. Treatment involves complete resection of tumour and chemotherapy.
